dataset.title: Microclimate at Harvard Forest HEM and LPH Towers since 2002

section.para: At all flux tower sites (HK1, M1) and at the understory dataloggers (LP225B, LP300B, HK2, HK3), microclimate data are collected every 60 seconds. Average, maximum and minimum values are calculated every 30 minutes, synchronously with the times at which 30-minute eddy fluxes are calculated.

This dataset is released to the public and may be freely downloaded. Please keep the designated Contact person informed of any plans to use the dataset. Consultation or collaboration with the original investigators is strongly encouraged. Publications and data products that make use of the dataset must include proper acknowledgement. For more information on LTER Network data access and use policies, please see: http://www.lternet.edu/data/netpolicy.html.

section.title: Microclimate sensors
section.para: Air and soil temperature thermocouple sensors: Copper-constantan, hand-made from wire supplied by Omega Engineering (Stamford, CT, USA). Photosynthetically active radiation (PAR): LI-190 SA quantum sensors--Licor. Co-located air temperature and relative humidity sensors (above-canopy only): Campbell HMP 45C. Radiation-shielded and ventilated precision air temperature sensors (above-canopy only): Met-One, Inc., Grants Pass, OR, USA). Soil moisture sensors: Campbell CS-616. Net radiometer: Kippen Zonen, NR-Lite.

section.title: Hemlock Tower
section.para: On the flux tower, the PAR and HMP 45C temperature and relative humidity sensors are about 24 m above the ground, higher than all but a few branches of the surrounding trees. The aspirated precision air temperature is at about 23 m above ground. The net radiometer is about 28.5 m above ground, near the height of the sonic anemometer and intake ports for the eddy flux system (29 m). The HK2 datalogger is 100 m from the tower at a compass bearing of about 200 degrees, and the HK3 datalogger is 100 m from the tower at a 230-degree bearing. Around each of these datalogger, 3 understory PAR sensors are located at randomly chosen distances of 30 to 50 m at compass bearings of 0, 120 and 240 degrees from the datalogger. Four 10-cm deep soil temperature thermocouples are at randomly chosen distances of 10 to 20 m due N, E, S, and W of each datalogger. Two pairs of thermocouples that measure understory air temperature at 20 cm and 1 m above ground, shielded from radiant exchange with the sky, are at randomly chosen distances of 10 to 20 m N and S of each datalogger.

section.title: Little Prospect Hill Tower
section.para: Microclimate and eddy covariance measurements were discontinued at this site at the end of December of 2010.

On the flux tower, the PAR sensor is at the level of the highest canopy branches (about 21 m above the ground), the HMP 45C temperature and relative humidity sensor is about 2 m higher than this, and the aspirated high precision temperature sensor is about 24 m above ground. The net radiometer is about 27 m above ground. The LP225B datalogger is 200 m from the tower at a compass bearing of 225 degrees, and the LP300B datalogger is 200 m from the tower at a 300-degree bearing. Around each of these, 3 understory PAR sensors are located at randomly chosen distances of 20 to 30 m at compass bearings of 0, 120 and 240 degrees from the datalogger. Four 10-cm deep soil temperature thermocouples are at randomly chosen distances of 10 to 20 m due N, E, S, and W of each datalogger. The thermocouples for soil temperature measurement are inserted at an angle of 45 degrees from horizontal, to increase the length of buried wire and reduce heat conduction from the surface to the buried thermocouple. Two pairs of thermocouples that measure understory air temperature at 20 cm and 1 m above ground, shielded from radiant exchange with the sky, are at randomly chosen distances of 10 to 20 m N and S of each datalogger.
